When i first started playing i mained top for years and Darius became my favorite champion. I switched to jungle because I liked the role more due to it having more agency and it being more fun. 


When I heard Darius was now a viable jungle option I was estatic. I've played him a few games jungle and have a fairly good win rate on him. I will say this. 


His clear speed in absolutely insane. I can clear 3:12 without even trying. Get your 5 stacks and move onto the next camp. His early game is also insane. No one but trundle or Olaf is beating you 1v1 early. This makes an invade of your jungle highly unlikely. Darius is also about as good of a 1v2 champ as you can get. I have lost count of the amount of double kills I've gotten with through the years. 



However he's still Darius and still has all the same issues as he does in top lane. He has terrible mobility and he gets kited easily. His ganks are weak. He also falls off late game. If your teammates feed and the enemy jungler gets ahead of you then you're next to useless. By that I mean with someone like ammumu you're still a threat even when behind due to your engage, ultimate and tankiness. With Darius if you're not getting kills then that's it you're done.
Easy answer. He steals the show everytime he's on screen

Length: Obviously, that's how long the rod is. Here's why it matters. For certain techniques you want a shorter rod and for some you want a longer rod. The longer the rod, the longer the cast. Of course you don't always need to make super long cast. For bass fishing all my cast are usually less than 20 yards. Shorter rods excel for techniques where you have to put a lot of action into the rod ie; a jerkbait. If you use a long rod for a jerk bait you will be hitting the side of the boat, ect. Longer rods excel for techniques like the a rig and big swimbaits since it allows more casting distance. 



Power: med-light, medium, med-heavy, heavy. It's how much pressure it takes to bend the rod. Why it matters is if you are throwing a light lure you want to use a lower power so you can cast further and more accurate. Power also helps with hook setting Power. You don't always want the most hook setting Power possible. Treble hook lures you don't need to set the hook hard since it's usually a lighter wire hook and it's exposed so it's possible that if you set the hook too hard then you will either rip the hook out of its mouth or you will make a hole so big the fish can easily throw the hook. For something with a thick hook like a frog you want more hook setting power


Action: moderate, moderate-fast, fast, extra fast. This is how far the rod will bend. Fast is the top 20% and moderate is more like the top 50%. This matters because for some lures you want a more moderate, or parabolic bend. The more moderate the rod, the more the rod will absorb the shock of the fish. This allows you to keep fish on the hook when they jump and it allows you to play with them a bit more. The faster the action also usually means you feel the bite faster, not necessarily better, but faster. But of course, you don't always want to feel the bite faster. Something like a jig you want to give the fish a second before setting the hook. 


Important to understand that these are not completely universal and it varies from brand to brand. Some brand's fast will be another brand's extra fast ect.


And the lure is just a guideline and is usually pretty helpful and accurate, but it is not the end all be all. I personally would not use a rod that short for frogs. The shortest I would go is 7 ft heavy-fast for open water frigging and 7'3 heavy-fast for frigging on top of mats. Everyone has their preferences and you will find your own through time.

I left Sac State 8 years ago and I'll tell you this from my experience. College is not the last place you will meet new people and make new friends, BUT it is the last EASY place you can meet new people and make new friends. Right now is a golden opportunity for this. Most people around you are around your general age group, are all pursuing the same goal, and likely have similar interests. Heck, you have clubs that are specifically formed around a very specific interest. Put your self out there and join every club or study group you can. Back then I didn't have the confidence to enjoy myself they way i should have, but don't let that stop you from going out there and meeting new people.

Chidori is nature transformation. Sasuke and Kakashi use their lightning release Chakra nature to create the chidori in the palm of their hand.

Raikiri takes it one step further and not only does he do the nature transformation adds shape manipulation into it. This shape manipulation changes the shape of the chidori into a pointed spear type shape.

If you're new and want to keep it simple. Just stick to 8 pound mono. It's cheap and a good beater line. I've used this for years when I've started and it was never an issue. I've always used Berkeley trilene for mono.



If you're more serious I use the following:

For braid is like suffix 832, but powerpro is really good to.  For fluorocarbon I like sunline sniper or segaur red label.

For frogs: 55 pound straight braid 

For soft texas rig, wacky rig, qrolina rig: 20 pound braid to 16 pound fluorocarbon. 

For drop shot or Ned rig: 20 pound braid to 10 pound fluorocarbon 

For crankbaits: 20 pound braid to 16 pound fluorocarbon 

For jerk baits: 20 pound braid to 12 pound fluorocarbon 

For topwater poppers, propbaits, buzzbaits, and walking baits: 20 pound braid to 12 pound monofilament 

For spinnerbaits or chatterbaits: 20 pound braid to 16 pound fluorocarbon
